Directions

This is a simulation of a piston/cylinder system, used to observe the ideal gas law in a variety of scenarios. Change the scenario using the drop-down menu labelled, "Scenario". Adjust the amount of heat added (or the external pressure) using the slider below the drop-down menu. View the governing equations by pressing the "Details" button to the right of the slider.

Details

Choose between the scenarios below

Constant pressure
Constant volume
Adiabatic and reversible
External spring
Constant temperature
The energy balance for the system is $$ [1] \quad \Delta U = Q + W $$ where \( \Delta U \) is the change to internal energy (J/mol), \( Q \) is heat added to the system (J/mol), and \( W \) is work performed on the system (J/mol). Work is defined $$ [2] \quad W = - P \Delta V $$ where \( P \) is internal pressure (Pa) and \( V \) is the volume of the piston/cylinder (m3). Therefore, $$ [3] \quad \Delta U + P \Delta V = Q $$ and $$ [4] \quad \Delta U + \Delta ( P V ) = Q $$ because \( \Delta P = 0 \). thus, $$ [5] \quad \Delta H = Q $$ where \( \Delta H \) is the change in enthalpy of the system (J/mol), because \( \Delta U + \Delta ( P V ) = \Delta H \). We can find the change in temperature knowing \( C_{P} \; \Delta T = \Delta H \): $$ [6] \quad C_{P} \; \Delta T = Q $$ where \( C_{P} \) is the constant-pressure heat capacity of the gas. For an ideal diatomic gas, \( C_{P} \) is \( \frac{7}{2} R \) where \( R \) is the ideal gas constant, approximately 8.314 J/mol. Finally, the volume of the cylinder can be calculated using the ideal gas law $$ [7] \quad PV = nRT $$ where \( n \) is the number of moles of gas in the cylinder.
The energy balance for the system is $$ [1] \quad \Delta U = Q + W $$ Where \( \Delta U \) is the change to internal energy (J/mol), \( Q \) is heat added to the system (J/mol), and \( W \) is work performed on the system (J/mol). For a constant-volume system, there is no work done on the cylinder. Therefore, $$ [2] \quad W = 0 $$ and $$ [3] \quad \Delta U = Q $$ Since \( U = C_{V} \; \Delta T \) where \( C_{V} \) is the constant-volume heat capacity [J/(mol K)], $$ [4] \quad C_{V} \; \Delta T = Q $$ Using the equation above, we can determine temperature of the system based on the amount of heat added, and using the ideal gas law we can determine the pressure of the system.
The energy balance for the system is $$ [1] \quad \Delta U = Q + W $$ Where \( \Delta U \) is the change to internal energy (J/mol), \( Q \) is heat added to the system (J/mol), and \( W \) is work performed on the system (J/mol). For an adiabatic system, heat added to the system is zero \( ( Q = 0 ) \). Therefore $$ [2] \quad \Delta U = W $$ and since \( W = -P dV \) where \( V \) is volume and \( P \) is pressure, and \( \Delta U = C_{V} \; dT \) where \( C_{V} \) is the constant-volume heat capacity of the ideal gas, $$ [3] \quad C_{V} \; dT = - P dV $$ Note that for an ideal diatomic gas, \( C_{V} \) is \( \frac{5}{2} R \) where \( R \) is the ideal gas constant, approximately 8.314 J/mol. We can substitute the ideal gas law \( P = \frac{nRT}{V} \) into the equation to yield $$ [4] \quad \frac{ C_{V} \; dT }{ T } = - \frac{ n R }{ V } dV $$ Integrating each side of the equation yields $$ [5] \quad C_{V} \; \mathrm{ ln } \left( \frac{ T_{ 2 } }{ T_{ 1 } } \right) = -n R \; \mathrm{ ln } \left( \frac{ V_{ 2 } }{ V_{ 1 } } \right) $$ This can be rearranged and the ideal gas law can be substituted to yield $$ [6] \quad \frac{ T_{2} }{ T_{1} } = \left( \frac{ P_{ 2 } }{ P_{ 1 } } \right)^{ R / C_{P} } $$ In this simulation, \( T_{1} \) is the initial temperature 273 K and \( P_{1} \) is the initial pressure of 1 atm (101325 Pa).
The energy balance for the system is $$ [1] \quad \Delta U = Q + W $$ Where \( \Delta U \) is the change to internal energy (J/mol), \( Q \) is heat added to the system (J/mol), and \( W \) is work performed on the system (J/mol). For a piston/cylinder with an internal spring, the internal pressure is the sum of the external pressure and the pressure applied by the spring's displacement: $$ [2] \quad dU = dQ - ( P_{ext} + P_{spr} ) dV $$ where \( P_{ext} \) is the external pressure outside the cylinder (Pa), and \( P_{spr} \) is the pressure applied by the spring (Pa). The pressure applied by the spring is $$ [3] \quad P_{spr} = k A \Delta z $$ where \( A \) is the area of the piston head (0.161 m2 in this simulation), \( k \) is the spring constant (which is 1x106 N/m in this simulation per spring. Since there are two springs, the effective spring constant is 2x106 N/m), and \( \Delta z \) is the spring displacement (m). In this simulation, the temperature, volume, and pressure are calculated iteratively. That is, temperature is first estimated assuming zero spring displacement: $$ [4] \quad C_{V} \; \Delta T = Q $$ then, pressure is estimated using the ideal gas law (in the first iteration, volume is 0.032 m3, corresponding to zero spring displacement): $$ [5] \quad PV = nRT $$ the resultant pressure is used to calculate the spring displacement using equation [3], and the spring displacement is used to find a more accurate value for \( V \) (m3). Finally, the new value for \( V \) is substituted into the equation below to find a more accurate value for \( T \) (the derivation of the equation below is beyond the scope of these details), $$ [6] \quad T = 273 + \frac{ Q - P_{ext} ( V - 0.032 ) - k \left[ \left( \frac{V^{2}}{2} - \frac{0.032^{2}}{2} \right) - 0.032 ( V - 0.032 ) \right] }{ C_{V} } $$ and the ideal gas law is then used to obtain a more accurate value for \( P \). This process is repeated 10 times, with values for \( P \), \( T \), and \( V \) each becoming more accurate with each iteration.
The energy balance for the system is $$ [1] \quad \Delta U = Q + W $$ Where \( \Delta U \) is the change to internal energy (J/mol), \( Q \) is heat added to the system (J/mol), and \( W \) is work performed on the system (J/mol). For a constant-temperature system, \( \Delta U = 0 \) because \( \Delta T = 0 \). Therefore, $$ [2] \quad 0 = dQ - PdV $$ the equation can be rearranged and integrated $$ [3] \quad Q = \int_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}} P dV $$ using the ideal gas law to substitute \( nRT / V \) for \( P \): $$ [4] \quad Q = \int_{V_{1}}^{V_{2}} \frac{ nRT }{ V } dV $$ this yields $$ [5] \quad Q = RT \; \mathrm{ln} \left( \frac{V_{2}}{V_{1}} \right) = - RT \; \mathrm{ln} \left( \frac{P_{ext}}{P_{init}} \right) $$ where \( P_{ext} \) is the final external pressure and \( P_{init} \) is the initial external pressure (1 atm in this simulation).
About

This simulation was created in the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, at University of Colorado Boulder for LearnChemE.com by Neil Hendren under the direction of Professor John L. Falconer. Address any questions or comments to learncheme@gmail.com. All of our simulations are open source, and are available on our LearnChemE Github repository.

Is your screen too small to fit this application? Try zooming-out on the web page (CTRL+"-" and CTRL+"=" on Windows, or ⌘+"-" and ⌘+"=" on Mac), then refreshing the page. This application is not compatible with Internet Explorer or web browsers that do not support WebGL and HTML5. Recommended browsers are the latest versions of: Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Edge, and Opera.
